content: Which of the following metrics definitions is not accurate?

options.label: A

content: In the quality improvement effort using statistical thinking, one of the following is correct except:

options.label: A
options.content: Control is defined as the complete absence of variation

options.label: B
options.content: Control is simply a state where all variation is predictable variation

options.label: C
options.content: A controlled process isn't necessarily a sign of good management, nor is an out-of-control process necessarily producing non-conforming product

options.label: D
options.content: We control the process through the use of past experience and to predict/expect the variation in the future at least within limits

content: One is correct about ‘Variation’ in a process.

options.label: A
options.content: All variations are caused and are a natural phenomenon

options.label: B
options.content: All processes will be subject to variation in performance

options.label: C
options.content: Non-random variations are not usually a planned part of the process variations

options.label: D
options.content: All variations are considered to be caused by chance

content: One is a wrong statement about systematic error of data.

options.label: A
options.content: It affects all measurements in the same way i.e., the accuracy of the measurement

options.label: B
options.content: They are avoided, i.e., they are determinate errors

options.label: C
options.content: They are inherent in the measuring system, and are unavoidable, i.e., they are indeterminate errors

content: Of the following, chose the wrong statement.

options.label: A
options.content: The key aspect of SPC is to obtain predictable processes that produce consistent results by quickly detecting the occurrence of assignable causes of process shifts

options.label: B
options.content: Predetermined control limits are defined by the capability of the process, whereas specification limits are determined by the customer needs

options.label: C
options.content: Control Limits are used to determine if the process is in a state of statistical control (i.e., is producing consistent output)

options.label: D
options.content: Specification Limits are used to determine if the product will function in the intended fashion

content: Pick the wrong statement.

options.label: A
options.content: A process is capable if individual products consistently meet specification

options.label: B
options.content: A process is stable (in control) only if common variation is present in the process

options.label: C
options.content: A process in statistical control will necessarily meet the design specifications

options.label: D
options.content: Process capability compares the output of an in-control process to the specification limits by using capability indices

content: One is correctly matched.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.content: Quality control- Can we done the job correctly?

options.label: C
options.content: Process control- Have we done the job correctly?

options.label: D
options.content: Process capability- Can we done the job correctly?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.content: The standard deviation does not reflect the magnitude of the sample data, only the scatter about the average.

options.label: D
options.content: The average value of the quality characteristic corresponding to in-control state is represented by center line (CL).

content: In a process, 18 out of 20 points are plotted above the center line (CL) but below the upper control limit, and only 2 of 20 are plotted between the center line and the lower control limit. The process state is said to be:

options.label: C
options.content: Data is not enough to predict

options.label: D
options.content: Process state is not dependent over this data

content: The main outcome of risk identification, in a risk management process, is to?

content: Which one is not correct about goal programming

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.content: The objective is to minimize the deviation between goals and actual result

content: Which one is the limitation of linear programming model?

options.label: A
options.content: Factors such as uncertainty and time are not taken into consideration

options.label: B
options.content: Parameters in the model are assumed to be constant but in real life situations they are not constants

options.label: C
options.content: Linear programming deals with only single objective

content: Consider the linear equation x1 + 3 x2 - 4 x3 + 2 x4 = 12. How many decision variables and constraints are defined by this equation respectively?

Suppose that the chance of rain tomorrow depends on previous weather conditions only through whether or not it is raining today and not on past weather condition. If it is raining today, then it will rain tomorrow with probability 0.75. If it is not raining today, then it will rain tomorrow with probability of 0.4. Calculate the probability that it will not rain two days from today given that it is raining today.

Arrivals at telephone booth are considered to be Poisson with an average time of 10 minutes between one arrival and the next. The length of phone call is assumed to be distributed exponentially, with mean 3 minutes. They are served in single server with infinite queue length. What is the probability that a person arriving at the booth will have to wait?
